questions.question_text:
An email analysis system notifies a security analyst that the following message was quarantined and requires further review.

From: CEO@CompTIA.org
To: Purchasing@CompTIA.org
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Gift card purchase ASAP
Body:

Please purchase gift cards to any major electronics store and reply with pictures of them to this email!

Which of the following actions should the security analyst take?

discussion.content:
Here is my analysis:
- B and D are discarded because this is not a security analyst responsibility.
- The EXTERNAL tag is used to review an email deeper for potential phishing activity.
- The sender domain seems to be right (we would have to analyze the email header to discard an open smtp relay for example, I'm talking base on my experience, but that is not available on this question lol).
- In the body message the "CEO" is asking to make a purchase and the gift cards purchased should be shared as an image in the reply but for what? I think this is the major red flag. And also, I gotta mention that "urgency" is taking place here ("asap") this is a common social engineering technique.
- In the item mentioned above I would reach out to CEO to validate this activity before taking the decision to release or delete the email because I don't discard their account has been compromised.
I have reasons to doubt about the origin or intentions of this e-mail to take the decision of releasing it, so I would delete it and block the sender, but again there are some other steps I would follow before taking this decision but due to the lack of context I think this is the right answer (C).

comments.content: Absolutely this. The "EXTERNAL" tag is what caught my eye. You are correct that having the headers to do a deep dive would be best. C is the correct answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I agree, C

choices.B: Immediately contact a purchasing agent to expedite.
choices.A: Release the email for delivery due to its importance.
choices.C: Delete the email and block the sender.
choices.D: Purchase the gift cards and submit an expense report

comments.content: D, Agreed. I did not catch that at first. This question is a little tricky if you are not paying attrention.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This answer has to be D. There's low traffic on Wednesday, outbound traffic maxes out at 300Mbps but Thursday has around 1000Mbps of outbound traffic at midnight, when the office is closed.
thank you guys for helping me understand this!

Selected Answer: D
It is D. 

There is a HUGE fall off at 1900 on inbound connections, and around 2100 there is a sharp increase of outbound traffic with no inbound traffic increase too match. Meaning whatever is being passed is only moving in 1 direction. Thus warrants further investigation.

comments.content: it's such a bad question though. To arrive at D means you need to know comptia is relying on reading into the question, rather than performing analysis.. because they specifically said there are no backups is the only reason to look at thursday over wednesday. Otherwise wednesday looks more anomalous

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
As stated below over the course of several comments:
Wednesday looks the most different but Thursday's is the only one where outbound data Far exceeds inbound data. It's also the only day with a lot of outbound data if you actually look at the numbers on the scale. The only thing that deterred me was that Thursday's looked like backup however the question specifically states "backups were not performed during this time". 
Also for an exam of this difficulty, for me it's just too easy that Wednesday is the answer as the other three days look so similar at a glance. We all know what CompTIA can be like for making us thoroughly read the question and this is another example of that.

I'm going with D

Whilst Wednesday looks lke the odd one out, when you look at how many Mbs of data are flooding out of the network then surely the early and late hours of Thursday are the biggest concern... Outbound traffic is heavy and far exceeding inbound at these times

comments.content:
It's a tricky one isn't it. Wednesday looks the most different but Thursday's is the only one where data out Far exceeds data in and it's a lot of data if you actually look at the numbers.

CopmTIA likes to be sneaky with questions and Wednesday just looks too easy of an answer
Please disregard lol I didn't pay attention to the scales, changing my answer to Thursday's logs (D).
For early hours from Thursday is because there is a continuity that is coming from wednesday night (most of the data was exfiltrated on wednesday though)
Though i've just realised the questions states "backups were not performed during this time" that's all the steer i need towards Thursday.... I'm going with D
...though i would say Thursday's looks like backup. I'm going with C but i'm not sure enough to vote for it.

Agree:
WS1 -> True Positive (Encrypt Entire Session)
WS2 -> False Positive (Submit as non-issue)
WS3 -> True Positive (Request certificate from a public CA)

discussion.content:
Agree with the solution:

Web Server 1 --> True positive - Encrypt entire session
Web Server 2 --> False Positive - Submit as non-issue
Web Server 3 --> True Positive - Request certificate from a public CA

Web Server 1 --> True positive - 
Web Server 2 --> False Positive 
Web Server 3 --> True Positive -

comments.content:
still avail here with the Vulnerability Scan Report thats missing
https://vceguide.com/when-you-have-completed-the-simulation-please-select-the-done-button-to-submit-once-the-simulation-is-submitted-please-select-the-next-button-to-continue-2/
thank you ! the full question is here! Makes way more sense wheat they are asking for now.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

The developers recently deployed new code to three web servers. A daily automated external device scan report shows server vulnerabilities that are failing items according to PCI DSS.

If the vulnerability is not valid, the analyst must take the proper steps to get the scan clean.

If the vulnerability is valid, the analyst must remediate the finding.

After reviewing the information provided in the network diagram, select the STEP 2 tab
to complete the simulation by selecting the correct Validation Result and Remediation
Action for each server listed using the drop-down options.


INSTRUCTIONS
-

STEP 1: Review the information provided in the network diagram.

STEP 2: Given the scenario, determine which remediation action is required to address the
vulnerability.

If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.


Step 1
-

//IMG//


//IMG//


//IMG//


//IMG//


Step 2:

//IMG//

An organization's Chief Information Security Officer has asked department leaders to coordinate on communication plans that can be enacted in response to different cybersecurity incident triggers.

Which of the following is a benefit of having these communication plans?

choices.D: They can help to keep the organization’s senior leadership informed about the status of patching during the recovery phase
choices.B: They can help to limit the spread of worms by coordinating with help desk personnel earlier in the recovery phase.
choices.C: They can quickly inform the public relations team to begin coordinating with the media as soon as a breach is detected
choices.A: They can help to prevent the inadvertent release of damaging information outside the organization

discussion.content: I think the communication plan is to put it on work throughout the entire incident response process and not only for the recovery phase. If you follow the communication plan since an incident has been confirmed you can avoid a potential unwanted information leak to the public that might cause a reputation damage for the company. Going with A here and also because is the most convenient for the organization.

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. They can help to prevent the inadvertent release of damaging information outside the organization.

Having communication plans in place in response to different cybersecurity incident triggers can help prevent the inadvertent release of damaging information outside the organization. When a cybersecurity incident occurs, it is important to have a clear and coordinated approach to communication within the organization. This ensures that accurate and controlled information is shared with the appropriate stakeholders, minimizing the risk of sensitive information being leaked or released to unauthorized individuals or the public.

Although other choices also make sense, the best "GENERIC" approach would be A as it says "in response to different cybersecurity incident triggers".
B is for worms
C is for specific breach that has taken place
D is for "vulnerability" as per patching

comments.content: Agree. Out of the options, this is the correct answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is the only answer that makes sense. B does nothing, C - no requirement to inform media at that time and D - Senior management don't need to know about patching updates.

questions.question_text: A network attack that is exploiting a vulnerability in the SNMP is detected. Which of the following should the cybersecurity analyst do FIRST?

comments.content: Agree. The FIRST thing would be to contain this mess and we can move on to patching or applying compensating controls (if any).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The next step after detecting an ongoing attack is to CONTAIN it. D is the optimal course of action in that regard.

Solution A should be done AFTER containing it, namely during the eradication phase.

B is incorrect because it doesn't provide the requisite immediacy. Also, senior management should have already provided basic guidance for situations like this in the form of training and administrative controls (policies and SOPs).

C only provides partial containment at best by hindering privilege escalation, which most likely isn't the only possible attack surface. It's not worth potentially disrupting those accounts' business activities just for a half-measure.

D is the only viable option. It's certainly no fix-all, but it'll at least obstruct the attacker immediately without unnecessarily disrupting business operations.
I think D makes sense, by following the incident response process this would be a containment action after detecting the attack. Further steps like applying patches would be the eradication.

choices.C: Disable all privileged user accounts on the network
choices.A: Apply the required patches to remediate the vulnerability
choices.B: Escalate the incident to the senior management team for guidance
choices.D: Temporarily block the attacking IP address
